{{Color box|#500000}} {{Color box|#FFFFFF}}{{cite web|url=http://brandguide.tamu.edu/electronic/colorPalette.html|title=Web Color Palette, Texas A&M University Brand Guide|work=Texas A&M University Brand Guide|publisher=Texas A&M University|accessdate=2009-09-30}} |mascot =[[Reveille (Texas A&M)|Reveille VIII]] |nickname =[[Texas A&M Aggies|Aggies]] |affiliations =[[Association of American Universities|AAU]], [[Big 12 Conference|Big 12]], [[Texas A&M University System]] |website=[http://www.tamu.edu/ tamu.edu] |logo=[[File:TAMU logo.png|center|220px]] |footnotes =All enrollment figures are as of 12th class day data of the spring 2011 semester }} '''Texas A&M University''' (often referred to as '''A&M''' or '''TAMU''') is a [[coeducation]]al [[public university|public]] research [[university]] located in [[College Station, Texas|College Station]], [[Texas]] (USA). It is the [[Flagship campus|flagship]] institution of the [[Texas A&M University System]]. The sixth-largest university in the United States, A&M's enrollment for Fall 2011 was over 50,000 for the first time in school history. {{Cite document|title=Enrollment Surpasses 50,000 For First Time In History|publisher=Texas A&M University|url=http://tamutimes.tamu.edu/2011/09/06/enrollment-surpasses-50000-for-first-time-in-history/|accessdate=2011-09-10|postscript=}} Texas A&M's designation as a [[land-grant university|land]], [[sea grant colleges|sea]], and [[space grant colleges|space grant]] institution reflects a broad range of research with ongoing projects funded by agencies such as the [[NASA|National Aeronautics and Space Administration]] (NASA), the [[National Institutes of Health]], the [[National Science Foundation]], and the [[Office of Naval Research]]. The school ranks in the top 20 American research institutes in terms of funding and has made notable contributions to such fields as [[animal cloning]] and [[petroleum engineering]]. The first public institution of higher education in Texas, the school opened on October 4, 1876{{cite web|url=http://marcomm.tamu.edu/documents/tamuFacts.pdf|format=PDF|title =Texas A&M University Facts|accessdate =2008-09-03|publisher =Texas A&M University}} as the [[History of Texas A&M University|Agricultural and Mechanical College of Texas]]. Its original mission was to educate males in farming and military techniques. Under the leadership of President [[James Earl Rudder]], in the 1960s A&M desegregated, became coeducational, and dropped the requirement for participation in the [[Texas A&M University Corps of Cadets|Corps of Cadets]]. To reflect the institution's expanded roles and academic offerings, the [[Texas Legislature]] renamed the school to Texas A&M University in 1963. The letters "A&M," originally short for "Agricultural and Mechanical," are retained only as a link to the university's past. The school's students, [[alumnus|alumni]], and sports teams are known as "[[Aggie#Schools|Aggies]]". The main campus is one of the largest in America, spanning {{convert|5500|acre|km2|0|sp=us}}, and includes the [[George Bush Presidential Library]]. Approximately one-fifth of the student body lives on campus. Texas A&M has approximately 800 officially recognized student organizations. Many students also observe the [[traditions of Texas A&M University]], which govern daily life as well as special occasions, including sports events. Varsity Aggie sports teams compete in the [[Big 12 Conference]]. However in July 2012, the school will join the [[Southeastern Conference]]. A&M operates two branches: [[Texas A&M University at Qatar|Texas A&M at Qatar]] and [[Texas A&M University at Galveston]]. Working with agencies such as the [[Texas AgriLife Research]] and [[Texas AgriLife Extension Service]], Texas A&M has a direct presence in each of the 254 counties in Texas. The university offers degrees in over 150 courses of study through ten colleges and houses 18 research institutes. Texas A&M has awarded over 320,000 degrees, including 70,000 graduate and professional degrees. As a [[Senior Military College]], Texas A&M is one of three public universities with a full-time, volunteer Corps of Cadets. It provides more commissioned officers to the [[Military of the United States|United States Armed Forces]] than any other school outside of the [[United States Service academies|service academies]].{{cite news|url=http://www.chron.com/disp/story.mpl/front/6161585.html|title=Bush urges A&M grads to consider a life of service|last=Kever|first=Jeannie|publisher=Houston Chronicle|date=2008-12-12}}

== History == {{Main|History of Texas A&M University}} [[File:TexasA&MCampus_1902.jpgâ|thumb|left|Texas A&M in 1902|alt=It shows, left to right, Ross Hall, Old Main, and Foster Hall.]] === Beginning years === The [[U.S. Congress]] laid the groundwork for the establishment of Texas A&M in 1862 with the adoption of the [[Morrill Act]]. The act auctioned land grants of public lands to establish endowments for colleges where the "leading object shall be, without excluding other scientific and classical studies and including military tactics, to teach such branches of learning as are related to agriculture and mechanical arts... to promote the liberal and practical education of the industrial classes in the several pursuits and professions in life". In 1871, the [[Texas Legislature]] used these funds to establish the state's first public institution of higher education,{{Cite document|title=The Texas Constitution, Article 7 - Education, Section 13 - Agricultural and Mechanical College|publisher=State of Texas|url=http://tlo2.tlc.state.tx.us/txconst/sections/cn000700-001300.html|accessdate=2007-08-06|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070610143937/http://tlo2.tlc.state.tx.us/txconst/sections/cn000700-001300.html |archivedate = June 10, 2007|deadurl=yes|postscript=}} the Agricultural and Mechanical College of Texas, then known as Texas A.M.C. [[Brazos County]] donated {{convert|2416|acre|km2|0|sp=us}} near [[Bryan, Texas]] for the school's campus.{{Cite document|title=Texas A&M University|work=[[Handbook of Texas]]|publisher=Texas State Historical Association|url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/TT/kct8.html|accessdate=2007-03-22|postscript=}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} Classes began on October 4, 1876, with 40 students and 6 faculty members. Admission was limited to white males, and all students were required to participate in the [[Texas A&M University Corps of Cadets|Corps of Cadets]] and receive military training.{{Cite document| last = Dethloff | first = Henry C.|authorlink=Henry C. Dethloff | title =A Pictorial History of Texas A&M University, 1876â1976 | place=College Station, Texas, Texas | publisher =Texas A&M University Press | year =1975 |pages=16â17| postscript = }} Enrollment climbed to 258 students before declining to 108 students in 1883, the year the [[University of Texas at Austin|University of Texas]] opened in [[Austin, Texas]].{{Cite book|last=Adams Jr.|first=John A.|title=Keepers of the Spirit|publisher=Texas A&M University Press|page=16, table 1â1|year=2001|isbn=1-58544-127-9|postscript=}} Though originally envisioned and annotated in the [[Texas Constitution]] as a branch of the [[University of Texas]], Texas A.M.C. had a separate Board of Directors from the University of Texas from the first day of classes and was never enveloped into the [[University of Texas System]]. [[File:TAMU Sul Ross statue.jpg|right|thumb|upright|Statue of [[Lawrence Sullivan Ross|Lawrence Sullivan "Sul" Ross]] located in front of the Academic Building|alt=A large domed building overlooks a full-length statue of balding white male with a mustache and long goatee and wearing a knee-length coat. The pedestal is engraved "Lawrence Sullivan Ross". ]] In the late 1880s, many Texas residents saw no need for two colleges in Texas and clamored for an end of Texas A.M.C. In 1891, Texas A&M was saved from potential closure by its new president [[Lawrence Sullivan Ross]], former [[governor of Texas]], and well-respected [[Confederate States of America|Confederate]] [[Brigadier General]]. Ross made many improvements to the school and enrollment doubled to 467 cadets as parents sent their sons to Texas A&M "to learn to be like Ross".{{Cite news|last=Ferrell|first=Christopher|title=Ross Elevated College from "Reform School"|newspaper=The Bryan-College Station Eagle|year=2001|url=http://209.189.226.235/aandmnews/anniversary/1rossbio.htm|accessdate=2007-03-22|postscript=}} During his tenure, many enduring [[Traditions of Texas A&M University|Aggie traditions]] were born, including the creation of the first [[Traditions of texas a&m#Aggie Ring|Aggie Ring]]. After his death in 1898, a statue was erected in front of what is now Academic Plaza to honor Ross and his achievements in the history of the school.{{cite web|last=Ferrell|first=Christopher|title=Ross Elevated College from "Reform School"|publisher=The Bryan-College Station Eagle|year=2001|url=http://209.189.226.235/aandmnews/anniversary/1rossbio.htm|accessdate=2007-03-22}} Under pressure from the legislature, in 1911 the school began allowing women to attend classes during the summer semester.{{Cite news | last=Kavanagh | first=Colleen | title=Questioning Tradition | newspaper=The Bryan-College Station Eagle | year=2001 | url=http://theeagle.com/aandmnews/anniversary/1questioningtradition.htm | accessdate=2008-06-24 | format= â [http://scholar.google.co.uk/scholar?hl=en&lr=&q=author%3AKavanagh+intitle%3AQuestioning+Tradition&as_publication=&as_ylo=2001&as_yhi=2001&btnG=Search Scholar search]|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20041226171757/http://theeagle.com/aandmnews/anniversary/1questioningtradition.htm |archivedate = December 26, 2004|deadurl=yes | postscript=}} At the same time, A&M began expanding its academic pursuits with the establishment of the [[Texas A&M College of Veterinary Medicine & Biomedical Sciences|School of Veterinary Medicine]] in 1915. === World Wars era === Many Texas A&M graduates served during [[World War I|World War I]]. By 1918, 49% of all graduates of the college were in military service, more than any other school. In early September 1918, the entire senior class enlisted, with plans to send the younger students at staggered dates throughout the next year. Many of the seniors were fighting in France when the war ended two months later.{{Cite news|last=Liffick|first=Brandie|title=Tradition spanning generations|newspaper=The Battalion|date=2001-10-30|url=http://media.www.thebatt.com/media/storage/paper657/news/2001/10/03/Ams125th/Tradition.Spanning.Generations-515912.shtml|accessdate=2007-03-22|postscript=}} Over 1,200 former students served as commissioned officers. After the war, Texas A&M grew rapidly and became nationally recognized for its programs in agriculture, engineering, and military science. The first graduate school was organized in 1924 and the school awarded its first Ph.D. in 1940. In 1925, Mary Evelyn Crawford Locke became the first female to receive a diploma from Texas A&M, although she was not allowed to participate in the graduation ceremony.{{Cite document | title=THE TEXAS A&M FOUNDATION MAGAZINE | SPRING 2010 | publisher=Texas A&M University Foundation | url=http://giving.tamu.edu/PDFs/Spring10_Spirit.pdf | accessdate=2011-02-16 | postscript=}} The following month the Board of Directors officially prohibited all women from enrolling. Many Aggies again served in the military during [[World War II]], with the college producing 20,229 combat troops. Of those, 14,123 Aggies served as officers, more than any other school and more than the combined total of the [[United States Naval Academy]] and the [[United States Military Academy]].{{Cite book|last=Adams Jr.|first=John A.|title=Keepers of the Spirit|publisher=Texas A&M University Press|year=2001|pages=160, 163|isbn=1-58544-127-9|postscript=}} During the war, 29 A&M graduates reached the rank of general. Enrollment soared after the war as many former soldiers used the [[G.I. Bill]] to further their education.{{Cite news | last=Gillentine | first=Kristy | title=Aggies recall days at Annex | newspaper=The Bryan-College Station Eagle | date=March 11, 2007 | url=http://theeagle.com/stories/031107/am_20070311019.php| accessdate=2008-06-24 | format= â [http://scholar.google.co.uk/scholar?hl=en&lr=&q=author%3AGillentine+intitle%3AAggies+recall+days+at+Annex&as_publication=&as_ylo=&as_yhi=&btnG=Search Scholar search]|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070930181709/http://theeagle.com/stories/031107/am_20070311019.php |archivedate = September 30, 2007|deadurl=yes | postscript=}} {{Wayback|url=http://theeagle.com/stories/031107/am_20070311019.php|date =20080615115959|bot=DASHBot}} In 1948, the state Legislature formally recognized Texas A&M as a separate university system from the University of Texas System, codifying the [[de facto]] arrangement between the schools.{{Cite document|title=A&M System History|publisher=Texas A&M University System|url=http://www.tamus.edu/regents/history/|accessdate=2011-02-16|postscript=}} === University era === On March 26, 1960, [[Major General]] [[James Earl Rudder]], class of 1932, became the 16th president of the college.{{Cite document|last=Dethloff|first=Henry C.|title=A Pictorial History of Texas A&M University, 1876-1976|place=[[College Station, Texas]]|publisher=Texas A&M University Press|year=1975|page=184|postscript=}} Rudder's tenure (1959â1970) marked a critical turning point in the school's history. Under his leadership, Texas A&M underwent a dramatic expansion in terms of its physical plant construction, but more importantly, it diversified and expanded its student body by admitting women and minorities. The Corps of Cadets became voluntary. In the face of growing student activism during the 1960s, Rudder worked diligently to ensure that school continue to fulfill its mission of providing a quality education for all Aggies. By his death in 1970, Rudder had overseen the growth of the school from 7,500 to 14,000 students from all 50 states and 75 nations.{{Cite document|last=Ferrell|first=Christopher|coauthors=|title=Rudder's influence is evident on campus|work=|pages=|language=|publisher=The Bryan-College Station Eagle|year=2001|url=http://209.189.226.235/aandmnews/anniversary/1rudderbio.htm|accessdate=2009-06-29|postscript=}}Christopher B. Bean, "James Earl Rudder and the Transformation of Texas A&M University," ''Journal of South Texas'' (Fall 2008), Vol. 21 Issue 2, pp 119-31 In 1963, the 58th [[Legislature of Texas]] approved of Rudder's changes, and officially renamed the school "Texas A&M University", specifying that the "A" and the "M" were purely symbolic, reflecting the school's past, and no longer stood for "Agricultural and Mechanical". In the following 35 years, Texas A&M more than tripled its enrollment from 14,000 students to over 45,000.{{Cite document|title=About Texas A&M University|publisher=Texas A&M University|url=http://www.tamu.edu/home/aboutam/|accessdate=2008-02-20|postscript=}} Much of the legislative work allowing the expansion of Texas A&M and the admission of women was pushed by [[Texas State Senate|State Senator]] [[William T. Moore (Texas politician)|William T. "Bill" Moore]], who served from 1949 to 1981. Known as "the Bull of the Brazos" and "the father of the modern Texas A&M University", Moore was a Bryan attorney and businessman originally from [[Wheelock, Texas|Wheelock]] in [[Robertson County, Texas|Robertson County]]. He also taught economics at TAMU prior to his entry into World War II.Robert C. Borden, "Bull of the Brazos dies: Moore was champion of Texas A&M," ''[[Bryan-College Station Eagle]]'', May 28, 1999, pp. 1-3 Texas A&M became one of the first four universities given the designation [[sea-grant university|sea-grant]] for its achievements in [[oceanography]] and marine resources development in 1971. In 1989, the university earned the title [[space-grant college|space-grant]] by [[NASA]], to recognize its commitment to space research and participation in the Texas Space Grant Consortium.{{cite encyclopedia|title=Texas A&M University|encyclopedia=Britannica|volume=1|publisher=[[EncyclopÃ¦dia Britannica]]|url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/589321/Texas-A-M-University|accessdate=2007-05-22}} [[File:George Bush Presidential Library.jpg|thumb|left|George Bush Presidential Library|alt=Above the doorway of a large, relatively plain rectangular structure with a short dome are the words "George Bush Library". In front of the building is a circular courtyard with a water fountain; eight American flags are positioned evenly around the circle.]] In 1997, the school became the home of the [[George Bush Presidential Library]]. Operated by the [[National Archives and Records Administration]], it is one of thirteen American [[Presidential library|presidential libraries]]. Former President [[George H.W. Bush|George Bush]] remains actively involved with the university, frequently visiting the campus and participating in special events.{{Cite document|url=http://bushlibrary.tamu.edu|title=Bush Library|publisher=George Bush Presidential Library and Museum|accessdate=2007-04-21|postscript=}}{{Cite document|title=George Bush Presidential Library and Museum Opens|publisher=The Record|DUPLICATE DATA: publisher=[[NARA]]|date=January 1998|url=http://www.archives.gov/publications/record/1998/01/bush.html|postscript=}} Texas A&M received national media attention on November 18, 1999, when [[Aggie Bonfire]], a ninety-year-old student tradition, collapsed during construction. Twelve current and former students died and twenty-seven others were injured. The accident was later attributed to improper design and poor construction practices.{{Cite document|last=Cook|first=John Lee, Jr.|title=Bonfire Collapse|publisher=[[U.S. Department of Homeland Security]]|url=http://www.usfa.dhs.gov/downloads/pdf/publications/tr-133.pdf|format=PDF|accessdate=2007-03-03|postscript=}} The victims' family members filed six lawsuits against Texas A&M officials, the student Bonfire leaders, and the university. Half of the defendants settled their portion of the case in 2005,{{Cite news|last=Kapitan|first=Craig|title=Bonfire case under scrutiny by court|newspaper=The Bryan-College Station Eagle|date=2006-09-03|url=http://209.189.226.235/stories/090306/am_20060903005.php|accessdate=2009-04-02|postscript=}} and a federal appeals court dismissed the remaining lawsuits against the university in 2007.{{Cite news|last=Van Der Werf|first=Martin|title=Appeals Court Upholds Dismissal of Lawsuits Over Texas A&M Bonfire Accident|newspaper=[[The Chronicle of Higher Education]]|date=2007-04-25|url=http://chronicle.com/news/article/2169/appeals-court-upholds-dismissal-of-lawsuits-over-texas-am-bonfire-accident|accessdate=2007-05-24|postscript=}} With strong support from [[Rice University]] and the [[University of Texas at Austin]], the [[Association of American Universities]] inducted Texas A&M in May 2001, on the basis of the depth of the university's research and academic programs.{{cite press release|title=Texas A&M Selected For Membership In Association Of American Universities|publisher=Texas A&M University|date=2001-05-07|url=http://tamunews.tamu.edu/archives/article.php?articleid=10936&month=5&year=2001|accessdate=2009-04-02}} In December 2006, university President [[Robert Gates]] resigned from his position to become the U.S. [[Secretary of Defense]].{{Cite news|last=Mengers|first=Katlynn|title=Search for new president begins|newspaper=The Battalion|date=2007-01-19|url=http://media.www.thebatt.com/media/storage/paper657/news/2007/01/19/News/Search.For.New.President.Begins-2654924.shtml|accessdate=2007-05-03|postscript=}} [[Elsa Murano]] became his replacement in January 2008, but later resigned in June 2009{{Cite news|last=Perez|first=Israel|url=http://www.dailytexanonline.com/state-local/survey-ranks-desirable-qualities-for-a-m-s-new-president-1.1868780|title=Survey ranks desirable qualities for A&M's new president|accessdate=2009-09-29|date=2009-09-08|newspaper=The Daily Texan|postscript=}} {{dead link| date=May 2010 | bot=DASHBot}} and was replaced by [[R. Bowen Loftin]]. In September 2011, Texas A&M announced that it will leave the [[Big 12 Conference]] for the [[Southeastern Conference]] in July 2012. {{cite news|title=SEC: Texas A&M to join in July 2012|url=SEC: Texas A&M to join in July 2012|accessdate=2011-09-28|newspaper=Associated Press|date=2011-09-05}} == Academics == === Student body === [[File:Bush Family Texas A&M Commencement Dec. 12, 2008.jpg|thumb|right|Then-President [[George W. Bush]] smiles with his parents, former President [[George H. W. Bush]], left, and former First Lady [[Barbara Bush]] following his commencement address at Texas A&M's December 2008 [[convocation]].|alt=The head and shoulders of three people - an older man, an older woman, and a middle-aged man - wearing formal robes are shown in front of a large circular seal. On the outer edges of the seal the letters "XAS A...IVERSITY...87..." are visible; an inner band of leaves separates the letters from a block T superimposed with a star.]] In the [[autumn|fall]] 2008 [[semester]], Texas A&M was the seventh largest [[List of largest U.S. universities by enrollment|American university]] with an enrollment of 48,039 students pursuing degrees in 10 academic colleges. The student body represents all 50 [[U.S. state]]s and 130 foreign countries. Texas residents account for 86% of the student population, and 28.9% are either of international origin or members of ethnic [[minority groups]]. The student body consists of 46.8% women and 53.2% men.{{cite web|url=http://www.tamu.edu/customers/oisp/student-reports/enrollment-profile-fall-2008.pdf|title=Texas A&M University Fall 2008 . Enrollment|accessdate=2011-03-22|pages=1â2|format=PDF|publisher =Texas A&M University}} Although Texas A&M is a secular institution, its student body has a reputation for being [[Religion in the United States|religious]] and [[Conservatism in the United States|conservative]]. According to a 2005 student survey published in [[the Princeton Review]], Texas A&M ranked 13th highest in the category "students pray on a regular basis."{{cite news|first=Allison|last=Miles|title=Princeton Review ranks A&M|url=http://media.www.thebatt.com/media/storage/paper657/news/2005/08/30/News/Princeton.Review.Ranks.Am-971738.shtml|publisher=The Battalion|date= 2005-08-30|accessdate=2009-01-26}} Four years later, the Princeton Review ranked Texas A&M the eighth most [[Social conservatism|socially conservative]] campus in the nation.{{cite encyclopedia|url=http://encarta.msn.com/encnet/Departments/College/?article=Top10MostConservative09|title=Top 10 Most Socially Conservative Colleges|accessdate=2009-01-26|publisher=Microsoft Encarta|archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5kwpYqjoQ |archivedate = October 31, 2009|deadurl=yes}} The Princeton Review also ranked the university in 2011 as the "17th least friendly" college in the [[US]] for [[LGBT]] people. {{cite web | url = http://www.princetonreview.com/schoollist.aspx?type=r&id=677&RDN=1 | title = LGBT-Unfriendly | accessdate = 2011-06-16 | date = 2011 | work = [[The Princeton Review]]}} The university consistently ranks among the top ten public universities each year in enrollment of [[National Merit]] scholars.{{cite web|title=National Freshmen Merit Scholars|url=http://www.ir.ufl.edu/nat_rankings/students/merit_old.pdf|format=PDF|publisher=University of Florida|accessdate=2007-03-12}} According to the [[College Board]], the fall 2008 entering freshman class consisted of 54% students in the top 10% of their high school graduating class, 86% in the top quarter, and 99% in the top half.{{cite web|url=http://collegesearch.collegeboard.com/search/CollegeDetail.jsp?collegeId=397&profileId=0|title=Student Body|publisher=[[College Board]]|accessdate=2009-04-02}} Seventy-four percent of these students took the [[SAT]]. The middle 50% of the freshmen had average scores as follows: in critical reading, 520â630, math, 560â670, and in writing 500â610. Twenty-six percent of the incoming freshmen took the [[ACT (examination)|ACT]], with the middle 50% scoring between a 23 and 29.{{cite web|title=SAT & ACT Policies|url=http://collegesearch.collegeboard.com/search/CollegeDetail.jsp?collegeId=397&profileId=6|accessdate=2009-04-02|publisher=College Board}} In the fall 2008 semester, the [[Dwight Look College of Engineering]] had the largest enrollment of 20.5%. The [[Texas A&M College of Liberal Arts|College of Liberal Arts]] and the [[Texas A&M College of Agriculture and Life Sciences|College of Agriculture and Life Sciences]] followed, enrolling 15% and 14% of the student body, respectively. The [[Texas A&M College of Education and Human Development|College of Education and Human Development]] enrolls 12%, and [[Mays Business School]] enrolled about 11%. Colleges with less than 10% enrollment included the [[Texas A&M College of Architecture|College of Architecture]], the [[Texas A&M College of Science|College of Science]], the [[George Bush School of Government and Public Service]], the [[Texas A&M College of Geosciences|College of Geosciences]], and the [[Texas A&M College of Veterinary Medicine & Biomedical Sciences|College of Veterinary Medicine & Biomedical Sciences]]. Approximately 8% of the student body had not declared a major. In the fall 2011 semester, enrollment at Texas A&M surpassed 50,000 for the first time. A record 50,054 students were enrolled on the census day.{{cite web|title=Enrollment Surpasses 50,000 For First Time In History |url=http://tamutimes.tamu.edu/2011/09/06/enrollment-surpasses-50000-for-first-time-in-history/|accessdate=2011-09-13|publisher=Texas A&M University}} === Rankings === {{Infobox US university ranking | ARWU_W = 100 | Forbes = 52 | QS_W = 158 | THES_W = 164 | USNWR_NU = 58 | Wamo_NU = 15 }} In the 2011 ''[[U.S. News and World Report]]'' ranking of [[public universities]], Texas A&M is listed 19th; among "national universities" the school is 58th.{{cite news|url=http://colleges.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/best-colleges/national-universities-rankings/page+3|title=America's Best Colleges 2011|accessdate=2010-08-17|date=2010-08-17|publisher=''U.S. News & World Report''}}In the ''U.S. News and World Report'' ranking, Texas A&M tied with [[Clemson University]], [[Fordham University]], [[Purdue University]], and the [[University of Minnesota]]. According to ''[[The Washington Monthly]]'' criteria, which considers research, community service, and social mobility, Texas A&M ranks fifth nationally.{{cite news|url=http://www.washingtonmonthly.com/college_guide/rankings/national_university_rank.php|format=PDF|title=National Universities|accessdate=2009-09-09|date=2009-09-09|publisher=The Washington Monthly}} The [[John Templeton Foundation]] listed Texas A&M as one of the thirty-five American college programs that "communicate[s] the values of honesty, trust, respect, responsibility, integrity, and fairness in the classroom".{{cite web|url=http://www.collegeandcharacter.org/guide/exemplary_honesty.html|title=The Templeton Guide: Academic Honesty Programs|accessdate=2007-05-17|publisher=John Templeton Foundation|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20071009203655/http://www.collegeandcharacter.org/guide/exemplary_honesty.html |archivedate = October 9, 2007|deadurl=yes}} The 2011 ''[[Kiplinger's Personal Finance]]'' ranked the school as the 23rd best-value public university on the basis of in-state tuition, and the 35th best-value public university on the basis of out-of-state tuition.{{cite news|url=http://content.kiplinger.com/tools/colleges/|title=Kiplinger's Best Values in Public Colleges|accessdate=2011-01-04|month=January|year=2011|publisher=Kiplinger}} After conducting a survey of leading employment recruiters, the [[Wall Street Journal]] ranked Texas A&M 2nd nationally, as "most likely to help students land a job in key careers and professions".{{cite news|title=The Top 25 Recruiter Picks |url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748704554104575435563989873060.html#|newspaper=Wall Street Journal|accessdate=13 September 2010|date=2010-09-13}}{{cite news|title=Schools' Rankings Calculated From 479 Recruiter Responses |url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748704358904575478074223658024.html?mod=googlenews_wsj|newspaper=Wall Street Journal|accessdate=13 September 2010|date=2010-09-13}} In 2009 the National Science Foundation has recognized Texas A&M as one of the top 20 research institutions.{{cite news|url=http://media.www.thebatt.com/media/storage/paper657/news/2009/11/04/News/National.Science.Foundations.Names.Texas.Am.Member.Of.Top.20.Research.Performers-3821378.shtml|title=National Science Foundations names Texas A&M member of Top 20 research performers|accessdate=2009-11-04|date=2008-11-04|publisher=Battalion}} Internationally, the university is also well-regarded. ''[[Newsweek International]]'' ranked Texas A&M as the 77th university globally on the basis of "openness and diversity" as well as "distinction in research".{{cite news|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/14321230/site/newsweek/|title=The Top 100 Global Universities|accessdate=2007-02-19|date=2006-08-13|publisher=[[MSNBC]] |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070212042830/http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/14321230/site/newsweek/ |archivedate = 2007-02-12}} In a comparison of educational quality, faculty quality, and research output, [[Shanghai Jiao Tong University]] ranked Texas A&M 53rd in the Americas{{cite web|url=http://www.arwu.org/Americas2009.jsp|title=Academic Ranking of World Universities - 2009, North & Latin America|accessdate=2010-05-03|publisher=Shanghai Jiao Tong University}} and 88th internationally.{{cite web|url=http://www.arwu.org/ARWU2009.jsp|title=Academic Ranking of World Universities - 2009|accessdate=2010-05-03|publisher=Shanghai Jiao Tong University}} ''[[The Times Higher Education Supplement]]'' listed Texas A&M 60th among the world's top 100 [[technology]] universities, 24th among America's top [[biomedicine]] universities, and 50th among North America's top 50 universities.{{cite news|url=http://www.thes.co.uk/statistics/international_comparisons/2006/top_america.aspx|title=North America's top 50 universities|accessdate=2007-02-19|date=2006-10-06|publisher=[[Times Higher Education|THES]]|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070225124036/http://www.thes.co.uk/statistics/international_comparisons/2006/top_america.aspx |archivedate = February 25, 2007|deadurl=yes}} The 2011 [[QS World University Rankings]]http://www.topuniversities.com/university-rankings/world-university-rankings/2011?page=3 ranked the university 158th overall in the world, 40 places up from 2010. [[File:Halbouty.JPG|left|thumb|The Michel T. Halbouty Geosciences Building houses the Department of Geology and Geophysics.|alt=Branches of a large oak tree shade a sidewalk]] === Endowment === Apart from revenue received from tuition and research grants, the university, as part of the [[Texas A&M University System]] (TAMUS), is partially funded from two endowments. The smaller endowment, totaling $1.17 billion in assets, is run by the private Texas A&M Foundation. A larger sum is distributed from the Texas [[Permanent University Fund]] (PUF). TAMUS holds a minority stake (one-third) in this fund; the remaining two-thirds belongs to the University of Texas system. As of 2006, the PUF ending net asset value stood at $10.3 billion; $400.7 million was distributed to the two university systems in fiscal year 2007.{{cite web|url=http://www.utimco.org/funds/allfunds/2006annual/puf_return.asp|title=Permanent University Fund|accessdate=2007-05-15|publisher=The University of Texas Investment Management Company}}{{cite web|url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/PP/khp2.html|title=Permanent University Fund|accessdate=2007-05-16|publisher=Texas State Historical Association}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} Combined, the total endowment for the TAMUS stands at $5.6 billion, as of 2006. === Research === [[File:Century Tree.jpg|thumb|right|The Century Tree, a famous campus landmark and subject to several traditions]] The Texas A&M University system, in 2006, was the first to explicitly state in its policy that technology commercialization was a criterion that could be used for [[tenure]]. Passage of this policy was intended to give faculty more academic freedom and strengthen the university's industry partnerships.{{cite press release|title=Regents Approve Patents and Commercialization of Research as New Consideration for Faculty Tenure|publisher=The Texas A&M University System|date=2006-05-26|url=http://sago-news.tamu.edu/releases/?p=166|accessdate=2009-04-11|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070506005421/http://sago-news.tamu.edu/releases/?p=166 |archivedate = May 6, 2007|deadurl=yes}} {{cite web|last=Butkus|first=Ben|title=Texas A&Mâs Use of Tech Commercialization As Basis for Awarding Tenure Gains Traction |publisher=Applied Biosystems|date=2007-08-06|url=http://www.genomeweb.com/biotechtransferweek/texas-am%E2%80%99s-use-tech-commercialization-basis-awarding-tenure-gains-traction|accessdate=2009-04-11}} Texas A&M works with both state and university agencies on various local and international research projects to forge innovations in science and technology that can have commercial applications. This work is concentrated in two primary locationsâResearch Valley and Research Park. Research Valley, an alliance of educational and business organizations, consists of {{convert|11400|acre|km2|-1|sp=us}} with {{convert|2500000|sqft|m2|-3|sp=us}} of dedicated research space. An additional {{convert|350|acre|km2|0|sp=us}}, with {{convert|500000|sqft|m2|-3|sp=us}} of research space, is located in Research Park.{{cite web|url=http://researchpark.tamu.edu/park/frequently-asked-questions-about-research-park.html|title=Frequently Asked Questions|accessdate=2007-01-01|publisher=Research Park}} Among the school's research entities are the [[Texas Institute for Genomic Medicine]], the [[Texas Transportation Institute]], the Cyclotron Institute, the [[Institute of Biosciences and Technology]], and the Institute for Plant Genomics and Biotechnology.{{cite web|title=Texas A&M University Centers and Institutes|publisher=Texas A&M University|url=http://researchpark.tamu.edu/centers|accessdate=2007-04-30}} In 2004, Texas A&M received nearly $570 million in research funding, ranking the school among the top 20 American research institutes.{{cite web|url=http://www.tamu.edu/home/research/|title=Texas A&M University Facts|accessdate=2007-01-01|publisher=Texas A&M University}} Almost $400 million of the grants were new awards. Throughout 2004, Texas A&M System faculty and research submitted 121 new inventions and established 78 new royalty-bearing licensing agreements; the innovations resulted in income of $8 million. The Texas A&M Technology Licensing Office filed for 88 [[patent]]s for protection of [[intellectual property]] in 2004.{{cite press release|url=http://vpr.tamu.edu/advance/2005/05_profile.pdf|title=Profile on Research and Graduate Studies|accessdate=2007-01-01|year=2005|format=PDF|publisher=Texas A&M University|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070614073424/http://vpr.tamu.edu/advance/2005/05_profile.pdf |archivedate = June 14, 2007|deadurl=yes}} Spearheaded by the [[Texas A&M College of Veterinary Medicine & Biomedical Sciences|College of Veterinary Medicine]], Texas A&M scientists created the first cloned domestic animal, a [[domestic cat|cat]] named 'cc', on December 22, 2001.{{cite news|title =First pet clone is a cat|publisher=BBC News|date=2002-02-15|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/science/nature/1820749.stm|accessdate=2009-04-05}} Texas A&M was also the first academic institution to [[cloning|clone]] each of six different species: cattle, a [[Boer goat]], pigs, a cat, a deer and a horse.{{cite news|last=Lozano|first=Juan A.|title=Texas A&M Cloning project raises questions still|publisher=Bryan-College Station Eagle|date=2009-06-27|url=http://209.189.226.235/stories/062705/am_20050627004.php|accessdate=2007-04-30}} In 2004, Texas A&M joined a consortium of universities to build the [[Giant Magellan Telescope]] in [[Chile]]. Estimated to be the largest optical telescope ever constructed, the facility will have seven mirrors, each with a diameter of {{convert|8.4|m|yd|1|sp=us}}. This will give the telescope the equivalent of a {{convert|24.5|m|yd|1|sp=us}} primary mirror and will be ten times more powerful than the [[Hubble Space Telescope]]. Construction is slated to be complete in 2016.{{cite web|url=http://gmto.org/ Giant Magellan Telescope|title=Giant Magellan Telescope|accessdate=2007-01-01|publisher=Giant Magellan Telescope}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}} As part of a collaboration with the [[United States Department of Energy|U.S. Department of Energy]]'s [[National Nuclear Security Administration]], Texas A&M completed the first conversion of a [[Texas A&M Nuclear Reactors|nuclear research reactor]] from using highly enriched [[uranium]] fuel (70%) to utilizing low-enriched uranium (20%). The eighteen-month project ended on October 13, 2006, after the first ever refueling the reactor, thus fulfilling a portion of [[President of the United States|U.S. President]] [[George W. Bush]]âs Global Nuclear Threat Reduction Initiative.{{cite news|url=http://media.www.thebatt.com/media/storage/paper657/news/2006/10/18/News/Am.Reactor.Gets.Safer.Uranium-2373962.shtml?norewrite200612140021&sourcedomain=www.thebatt.com|title=A&M reactor gets safer uranium|accessdate=2007-01-01|date=2006-10-18|publisher=The Battalion}} === Worldwide === [[File:TAMUQ Profs and Students.jpg|thumb|Two professors, a graduate, and an undergraduate student at the [[Texas A&M University at Qatar|TAMUQ branch campus]]|alt=Four people standing behind a flag each holding their thumb in the air]] Texas A&M has participated in over 500 research projects in over 80 countries and leads the [[Southwestern United States]] in annual research expenditures. The university conducts research on every continent and has formal research and exchange agreements with 100 institutions in 40 countries. Texas A&M ranks 13th among U.S. research universities in exchange agreements with institutions abroad and student participation in study abroad programs, and has strong research collaborations with the National Natural Science Foundation of China and many leading universities in China.{{cite web|url=http://rgs.tamu.edu/texas-a-m-rankings|title=Texas A&M Rankings|accessdate=2011-02-16|publisher=Texas A&M University Research and Graduate Studies |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070708171117/http://vpr-zope.tamu.edu/core/vpr.tamu.edu/nfo/brief-guide-to-research.html |archivedate = July 8, 2007}} Texas A&M owns three international facilities, a multipurpose center in Mexico City, Mexico, the Soltis Research and Education Center near the town of San Isidro, [[Costa Rica]], and the Santa Chiara Study Abroad Center in [[Castiglion Fiorentino]], Italy.{{cite web|title=International Programs Office|work=International Programs Office|publisher=Texas A&M University|url=http://international.tamu.edu/|accessdate=2007-05-22}}{{cite web|url=http://media.www.thebatt.com/media/storage/paper657/news/2009/03/09/News/A.Piece.Of.Am.In.The.Rainforest.Of.Costa.Rica-3665056.shtml?reffeature=textemailedition|title=A piece of A&M in the rainforest of Costa Rica: Center offers students chance to study abroad amid preserved natural scene|last=Lee|first=Jane|date=2009-03-09|publisher=The Battalion|accessdate=2009-03-09}} In 2003, over 1,200 Aggie students, primarily undergraduates, studied abroad.{{cite web|url=http://international.tamu.edu/ips/IntEdReports.asp|title=International Programs Reports|accessdate=2011-02-16|publisher=International Programs Texas A&M University|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070116115959/http%3A//international.tamu.edu/Overview.asp |archivedate = January 16, 2007}} Additionally, the university includes two branch campuses: [[Texas A&M University at Qatar|Texas A&M at Qatar]] located in [[Education City, Qatar|Education City]] in [[Doha, Qatar]] devoted to engineering disciplines{{cite web|title=Texas A&M University at Qatar|publisher=Texas A&M University|url=http://www.qatar.tamu.edu/|accessdate=2007-04-30}} and [[Texas A&M University at Galveston]] in [[Galveston, Texas]], devoted to marine research and host to the Texas Maritime Academy.{{cite web|title=Texas A&M University at Galveston|publisher=[[The Handbook of Texas]]|url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/TT/kct42.html|accessdate=2007-05-22}} Texas A&M's Center for International Business Studies is one of 28 supported by the [[U.S. Department of Education]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ed.gov/programs/iegpscibe/grantees.html|title=Centers for International Business Education|accessdate=2007-01-01|date=2005-02-16|publisher=U.S. Department of Education}} The university is also one of only two American universities in partnership with [[CONACyT]], Mexico's equivalent of the [[National Science Foundation]], to support research in areas including biotechnology, telecommunications, energy, and urban development.{{cite web|url=http://conacyt.tamu.edu/|title=Collaborative Research Grant Program|accessdate=2007-01-01|publisher=Texas A&M University-CONACYT}} In addition, the university is the home of "Las Americas Digital Research Network", an online architecture network for 26 universities in 12 nations, primarily in Central and South America.{{cite web|url=http://archone.tamu.edu/~americas/|title=Introduction|accessdate=2007-01-01|publisher="Las Americas" Digital Research Network}} == Campus == [[File:TAMUcampus.jpg|thumb|right|A view of the main campus, looking north from Kyle Field. At the center is the Academic Building with its copper dome]] {{Main|Campus of Texas A&M University}} Texas A&M's [[College Station]] campus, one of the largest in America, spans {{convert|5200|acre|km2|0|sp=us}} plus {{convert|350|acre|km2|0|sp=us}} for Research Park. The university is part of the [[Bryan-College Station metropolitan area]] located within [[Brazos County, Texas|Brazos County]] in the [[Brazos Valley]] (Southeast Central Texas) region, an area often referred to as "Aggieland". {{cite web|title=Appelt Aggieland Visitor Center|publisher=Texas A&M University|year=2007|url=http://visit.tamu.edu/|accessdate=2011-02-16}} According the [[United States Census|U.S. Census Bureau]], as of 2008, the population of Brazos County is estimated at 175,122.{{cite web|title=Brazos County, Texas- Population Finder- American Fact Finder|publisher=United States Census|year=2008|url=http://factfinder.census.gov/servlet/SAFFPopulation?_event=Search&_name=brazos+county&_state=&_county=brazos+county&_cityTown=brazos+county&_zip=&_sse=on&_lang=en&pctxt=fph|accessdate = 2009-04-05}} ''[[Money Magazine]]'', in 2006, named College Station the most educated city in Texas, and the 11th most educated American city, due largely to the size of the university.{{cite news|url=http://money.cnn.com/magazines/moneymag/bplive/2006/top25s/educated.html|title=Most educated|accessdate=2007-02-03|publisher=Money Magazine}} Aggieland is centrally located within {{convert|200|mi|km|-1|sp=us}} of three of the 10 largest cities in the United States and 75% of the [[Texas]] and [[Louisiana]] populations (approximately 13.1 million people). The area's major roadway is [[Texas State Highway 6|State Highway 6]], and several smaller state highways and [[Farm to Market Road]]s connect the area to larger highways such as [[Interstate 45]].{{cite web|title=Bryan-College Station: Quick Facts|publisher=Bryan-College Station (Texas) Chamber of Commerce|year=2007|url=http://www.bcschamber.org/LiveWork/BCSQuickFacts/|accessdate=2009-04-05}} The campus is bisected by a railroad track operated by [[Union Pacific Railroad|Union Pacific]].{{cite news|last=Jackson|first=Luke|coauthors=|title=Union Pacific, Texas A&M, CS officials agree to slow trains|publisher=The Battalion|date=2004-10-01|url=http://media.www.thebatt.com/media/storage/paper657/news/2004/10/01/News/Union.Pacific.Am.Cs.Officials.Agree.To.Slow.Trains-738969.shtml|accessdate=2007-04-18}} The area east of the tracks, known as Main Campus, includes buildings for the colleges of engineering, architecture, geosciences, science, education and liberal arts. Dormitories, as well as the main dining centers and many campus support facilities, are also on Main Campus. Notable buildings on Main Campus include [[Kyle Field]], Sterling C. Evans Library,the Academic Building, Harrington Hall, the Memorial Student Center, the Administration Building, Rudder Tower, Albritton Bell Tower, and the [[Bonfire Memorial]].{{cite press release|title=Free On-Campus Bus Service Offered at Texas A&M University|publisher=Texas A&M University|date=1996-11-06|url=http://tamunews.tamu.edu/archives/article.php?articleid=599&month=9&year=1996|accessdate=2007-04-18}} To the west of the railroad tracks lies West Campus, which includes most of the sports facilities, the business school, agricultural programs, life sciences, the veterinary college, the political science and economics school, the [[George Bush School of Government and Public Service]], the [[George Bush Presidential Library]] and two schools within the [[Texas A&M Health Science Center]]. Research Park, the area of West Campus along [[Farm to Market Road 60|Kimbrough Boulevard]], includes many research facilities.{{cite web|title=The Campus in 2020: Connect East and West Campus|publisher=Texas A&M University|year=2007|url=http://vision2020.tamu.edu/|accessdate=2011-02-16}} == Student life == === Residential life === [[File:Sbisa.jpg|Sbisa Dining Hall and central utility plant water tower sporting the greeting, "Welcome to Aggieland"|thumb|right]] During the 2006 fall semester, 20.5 percent of the student body lived on campus in one of two distinct housing sections located on opposite ends of campus. Both the Northside and Southside areas contain student dormitories, also known as residence halls. While some halls are single-sex, others are [[co-educational]]. Usually students of different genders live on alternate floors, although some halls are segregated by room or suite.{{cite news|last=Womack|first= Stuart|coauthors=|title=Dorms Go Through Changes|publisher=The Battalion|date=2006-08-23|url=http://media.www.thebatt.com/media/storage/paper657/news/2006/08/23/News/Dorms.Go.Through.Changes-2237564.shtml|accessdate=2007-04-30}} Residence hall styles vary. Many halls offer only indoor access to individual rooms, but other halls locate room entrances on an outdoor balcony. Room sizes vary by building. Halls with larger rooms include en-suite or private bathrooms, while halls with smaller rooms have a common bathroom on each floor. Several halls include a "substance-free" floor, where residents pledge to avoid bringing [[alcoholic beverage|alcohol]], [[recreational drug use|drugs]], or [[cigarette]]s into the hall.{{cite news|title=A New Place to Hang Your Hat|publisher=The Battalion|date=2002-09-02|url=http://media.www.thebatt.com/media/storage/paper657/news/2002/09/02/Campus/A.New.Place.To.Hang.Your.Hat-518397.shtml|accessdate=2007-04-30}} Northside consists of 17 student residence halls, including the 3 university honors dorms.{{cite web|title=Northside Halls|publisher=Texas A&M University|year=2007|url=http://reslife.tamu.edu/housing/halls/location/northside.asp|accessdate=2007-04-30}} Two of the university honors dorms are freshman only. The halls are located near local entertainment district [[Northgate, TX|Northgate]], and offer convenient access to campus dining establishments: Sbisa Dining Hall, The Underground and Bernie's Cafe. The demolition of Moore Hall, Crocker Hall, and McInnis Hall is scheduled for August 2011.{{cite news|last=Thompson|first= Connie|title=Northside halls to be torn down for new residence|publisher=The Battalion|date=2010-09-23|url=http://www.thebatt.com/news/northside-halls-to-be-torn-down-for-new-residence-1.1645136|accessdate=2010-10-04}} A $58 million 600-bed residence hall will replace the demolished halls that have accommodated roughly the same number. Some halls (particularly Walton) have unofficially claimed tables within the Sbisa Dining Hall and many halls congregate for dinner at a specific time each weekday.{{cite news|last=Hixson|first=Josh|title=Dorm Wars|publisher=The Battalion|date=2006-02-01|url=http://media.www.thebatt.com/media/storage/paper657/news/2006/02/01/Aggielife/Dorm-Wars-1546726.shtml|accessdate=2007-04-30}} Several of the residence halls located on Southside are reserved for members of the [[#Corps of Cadets|Corps of Cadets]]. Non-corps halls in this area center around the Commons, a hub for activities and dining.{{cite web|title=Residence Halls by Style â Commons|publisher=Texas A&M University|year=2007|url=http://reslife.tamu.edu/housing/halls/style/commons.asp|accessdate=2007-04-30}} Southside has two Learning Living Communities, which allow freshmen to live in a cluster with other students who share common interests.{{cite web|title=Leadership Living Learning Communities|publisher=Texas A&M University Department of Residence Life|url=http://reslife.tamu.edu/housing/llc/|accessdate=2007-05-22}} Facilities for the Corps of Cadets are located in the Quadrangle, or [[List of Texas Aggie terms#Q|"The Quad"]], an area consisting of dormitories, Duncan Dining Hall, and the Corps training fields.{{cite web|title=Cadet Resident Handbook|publisher=Texas A&M University|month=May|year=2006|url=http://corpshousing.tamu.edu/|accessdate=2007-04-30}} The Corps Arches, a series of 12 arches that "[symbolize] the spirit of [[#12th Man|the 12th Man]] of Texas A&M", mark the entrance to the Quadrangle.{{cite web|title=Corps Arches- Texas A&M University|publisher=Texas A&M University Corps of Cadets|url=http://tamu.edu/home/aboutam/campuslife/attractions/corpsArches.html|accessdate=2009-04-05}} All cadets, except those who are married or who have had previous military service, must live in the Quad with assigned roommates from the same unit and graduating class. [[Reveille (Texas A&M)|Reveille]], the Aggie [[mascot]], lives with her handlers in the Quadrangle.{{cite web|title=Cadet Resident Handbook|publisher=Texas A&M University Corps of Cadets|url=http://corpshousing.tamu.edu/|accessdate=2007-04-30}} === Corps of Cadets === {{Main|Texas A&M University Corps of Cadets}} [[File:AggieBandFormation.jpg|thumb|right|The [[Fightin' Texas Aggie Band|Fightin' Texas Aggie Band's]] Bugle Rank leads the band at halftime at a football game.|alt=Row of students in uniform with knee-high boots. Each holds a bugle that dangles a pennant.]] Texas A&M is one of six United States [[Senior Military College]]s. The schools' [[Texas A&M University Corps of Cadets|Corps of Cadets]] (or ''the Corps'') is the United States' largest uniformed student body outside the [[service academy|service academies]]. Many members participate in [[ROTC]] programs and earn commissions in the [[United States Armed Forces]] upon graduation. Members of the Corps have served in every [[armed conflict]] fought by the United States since 1876, and over 225 have served as [[general]]s or [[Flag Officers]].{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2004/ALLPOLITICS/05/13/texas/index.html|title=A&M cadets staunchly conservative|publisher=CNN|accessdate=2008-02-18|date=2004-05-13|last=Moghe|first=Sonia}} Until 1965, Corps membership was mandatory. The Corps welcomed female members in the fall of 1974,{{cite news|last=Nauman|first=Brett|title=Women Joined Corps 30 Years Ago|publisher=The Bryan-College Station Eagle|date=2004-09-10|url=http://209.189.226.235/aandmnews/091004womencadets.php|accessdate=2000-04-02}} and as of fall 2007, the co-ed Corps boasts an enrollment of 1,887 cadets. [[File:RobertGates TAMU SeniorBoots.JPEG|thumb|left|[[Robert Gates]] and senior cadets from the Corps of Cadets give the "gig 'em" sign at the [[The Pentagon|Pentagon]].]] The Corps is composed of two Air Force Wings, three Army Brigades, two Navy and Marine Regiments, and a joint military unit called The Task Force, as well as the [[Fightin' Texas Aggie Band]], whose members may be affiliated with any military branch.{{cite web|url=http://www.aggiecorps.org/about-the-corps/the-texas-aam-corps-of-cadets.html|title=The Texas A&M Corps of Cadets|publisher=Texas A&M Corps of Cadets|accessdate=2011-02-16}} Parson's Mounted Cavalry is the only mounted ROTC unit in the United States.{{cite web|url=http://www.tamu.edu/admissions/catalogs/06-07_UG_Catalog/gen_info/campus_life/corps/corps_activities.htm|title=Campus Life: The Corps Experience|publisher=Texas A&M University|accessdate=2007-05-18}}{{dead link|date=September 2010}} The Ross Volunteer Company, the oldest student-run organization in the state, is the official honor guard for the [[Governor of Texas]].{{cite web|url=http://aggiecorps.tamu.edu/About/default.htm|title=About the Corps|publisher=[[Texas A&M University Corps of Cadets]]|accessdate=2009-04-05}} {{dead link| date=May 2010 | bot=DASHBot}} The Fish Drill Team, a precision, close-order rifle drill team composed entirely of Corps freshmen, represents the school in local and national competitions. They have won the national championship almost every year since their creation in 1946, and have appeared in several Hollywood productions, with prominent roles in the movies ''[[A Few Good Men (film)|A Few Good Men]]'' and ''[[Courage Under Fire]]''.{{cite news|last=Nading|first=Tanya|title=Corps Fish Drill Team Reinstated|publisher=The Battalion|date=2001-11-02|url=http://media.www.thebatt.com/media/storage/paper657/news/2001/11/02/FrontPage/Corps.Fish.Drill.Team.Reinstated-516243.shtml|accessdate=2007-04-13}} The [[Fightin' Texas Aggie Band]], the world's largest precision [[military band|military]] [[marching band]], provides music for University functions and presents intricate halftime performances at football games. Some band drills are so complicated that they require band members to step between each other's feet to complete the maneuvers.{{cite web|url=http://www.aggieband.org/visitors-about.php|title=The Fightin' Texas Aggie Band|publisher=Aggie Band Association|accessdate=2007-05-18|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070520072141/http://www.aggieband.org/visitors-about.php |archivedate = May 20, 2007|deadurl=yes}} These drills must be drawn by hand as computer marching programs have returned errors; their calculations require two people to be in the same spot at the same time.{{cite web|url=http://b-batt.tamu.edu/dwnld/040918-jumbo-clem.wmv|title=The Aggie Band: Doing the Impossible|publisher=Former Student's Association|format=WMV|accessdate=2007-05-18|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070614135744/http://b-batt.tamu.edu/dwnld/040918-jumbo-clem.wmv |archivedate = June 14, 2007|deadurl=yes}} === Activities === [[File:TAMUsingingcadets.jpg|thumb|right|The Texas A&M University Singing Cadets]] Texas A&M has over 800 student organizations, including academic, service, religious, [[Fraternities and sororities|Greek]], and common interest organizations. Orientation programs encourage students to become involved in campus activities and organizations from the beginning.{{cite news|url=http://www.aggienetwork.com/HTMLEmails/DecSpENewsletter/newsletter.html|title=Texas A&M Association of Former Students E-Newsletter; Special Edition, December 4, 2003|accessdate=2007-01-02|date=2003-12-04|publisher=Texas A&M Association of Former Students}} An April 2005 campus survey found that 74% of the students were currently involved with at least one organization and that 88% participated in a campus organization in the past.{{cite web|title=Student Organization Involvement Survey|publisher=Texas A&M University Student Life Studies|month=April|year=2005|url=http://studentlifestudies.tamu.edu/results/Aggie_Rrring/StudentOrganizationInvolvementReport--highlightversion--4-29-2005.pdf|format=PDF|accessdate=2007-03-10}} One of the oldest student organizations is the [[Texas A&M Singing Cadets|Singing Cadets]], founded in 1893. Known as the "Voice of Aggieland", the Singing Cadets are an all-male choral group with about 70 members. The group travels nationally and has completed several international tours; most recently, South Africa in 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.thebatt.com/2.8485/singing-cadets-make-way-to-south-africa-1.1283353|title=Singing cadets make way to South Africa|accessdate=2011-03-13|date=2010-02-09|publisher=The Battalion}} [[Texas A&M Hillel]], the oldest Hillel organization in the United States, was founded in 1920 at the original college. The organization occurred three years before the national [[Hillel Foundation]] was organized at [[University of Illinois]].{{cite book|last=Umansky|first=Ellen M.|title=From Christian Science to Jewish Science: Spiritual Healing and American Jews|publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]|page=160|url=http://books.google.com/?id=abwSjUgVQwIC&pg=PA160&dq=texas+a%26m+hillel|isbn=0195044002|year=2005}}{{cite news|url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_hb5092/is_200505/ai_n18521479/|publisher=[[The Jewish Week]]|title=A Cushy Fit In Bush Country|last=Birkner|first=Gabrielle|date=2005-05-06|accessdate=2007-12-30}} {{dead link| date=May 2010 | bot=DASHBot}} [[File:TAMU Rec2.JPG|thumb|Student Rec Center|left]] [[GLBT Aggies]] is the descendant organization of Gay Student Services (GSS), the only student organization to ever successfully sue the institution for official recognition. {{cite news | title = GLBT Aggies recognize court-battled founding | date = 04/1/2008 | url = http://www.thebatt.com/2.8485/glbt-aggies-recognize-court-battled-founding-1.1186882 | work = [[The Battalion]] | accessdate = 2011-06-16}} In the decision [[Gay Student Services v. Texas A&M University]] the [[Fifth U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals]] held that the [[First Amendment]] required public universities to recognize student organizations aimed at [[gay]] students. quoted in {{Cite news|last=Wiessler|first=Judy|title=A&M loses 9-year battle in gay case|date=April 1, 1985|newspaper=Houston Chronicle|url=http://www.chron.com/CDA/archives/archive.mpl?id=1985_5727|accessdate=October 28, 2009|page=Section 1, page 1|postscript={{inconsistent citations}}}} The Graduate Student Council, founded in 1995, serves as the student government for Texas A&M Universityâs graduate and professional students. It is a council representing all TAMU graduate students with a purpose to improve graduate studentsâ academic, living and social experiences. The GSC represents studentâs concerns and is their liaison with the University Administration.{{cite web|url=http://gsc.tamu.edu/|title=Graduate Student Council(GSC)|accessdate=2010-06-16}} Students [[exercise]] at the Student Rec Center, a three-story facility encompassing {{convert|373000|sqft|m2|-1|sp=us}}, which includes exercise equipment, athletic courts, an indoor running track, a rock-climbing tower, and one of the top competitive pools and diving wells in America. The Rec Center also organizes intramural sports throughout the year.{{cite web|title=The Texas A&M Student Recreation Center|publisher=Texas A&M University|year=2008 |url=http://recsports.tamu.edu/facilities/student_rec_center/|accessdate=2009-04-12}} Some national service organizations originated at A&M. Aggie students founded the largest one-day student-run service project in America known as The Big Event. The annual service project allows students to give back to their community by assisting local residents.{{cite web|url=http://bigevent.tamu.edu/|title=The Big Event|accessdate=2007-05-15|publisher=The Big Event|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070510220954/http://bigevent.tamu.edu/ |archivedate = May 10, 2007|deadurl=yes}} The organization CARPOOL, a student run, [[designated driver|safe ride program]] has provided over 179,000 free rides (as of January 2011) to Aggies unable to transport themselves home. Its organizers also assist other universities in establishing similar programs.{{cite news|url=http://www.rocktownweekly.com/news_details.php?AID=35183&CHID=2|title=SafeRides Gives 10,000th Ride Home|work=The Daily News Record|accessdate=2009-02-03|date=2009-02-03|last=Bowser|first=Heather}}{{cite web|url=http://carpool.tamu.edu/|title=CARPOOL|accessdate=2007-01-02|publisher=CARPOOL}} In addition, the [[Corporation for National and Community Service]] listed A&M among the 500 academic institutions in the 2005â06 President's Higher Education Community Service Honor Roll.{{cite web|url=http://www.learnandserve.gov/pdf/honorroll_full.pdf|format=PDF|title=The President's Higher Education Community Service Honor Roll, 2005-06|accessdate=2007-04-12|publisher=Corporation for National and Community Service}} The Student Government Association (SGA), one of A&M's largest organizations, consists of over 1,300 student members in 3 branches, 15 committees, and 4 commissions. SGA has changed little since 1972, except its relative position within the official framework of the university.{{cite web|title=Student Government Association|publisher=Texas A&M University|year=2009|url=http://sga.tamu.edu/|accessdate=2009-05-09|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080522064338/http://sga.tamu.edu/ |archivedate = May 22, 2008|deadurl=yes}} === Media === ''[[The Princeton Review]]'' ranked ''[[The Battalion]]'', founded in 1893, as the 5th best college newspaper in America in 2010.{{cite web|title=The Princeton Review: 2008 Best Colleges Rankings|publisher=Princeton Review|date=2007-08-31|url=http://www.princetonreview.com/college/research/rankings/rankingDetails.asp?categoryID=7&topicID=57|accessdate=2008-01-30|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080221013857/http://www.princetonreview.com/college/research/rankings/rankingDetails.asp?categoryID=7&topicID=57 |archivedate = February 21, 2008|deadurl=yes}} Students also publish a secondary school newspaper, the ''Maroon Weekly''.{{cite web|title=The Maroon Weekly: About Us|publisher=The Maroon Weekly|url=http://www.maroonweekly.com/about.aspx|date=2007-06-30|accessdate=2007-06-30|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070823035514/http://www.maroonweekly.com/about.aspx |archivedate = August 23, 2007|deadurl=yes}} The ''Aggieland'', formerly known as ''The Olio'' and ''The Longhorn'', is one of America's largest college yearbooks in number of pages and copies sold.{{cite web|url=http://aggieland.tamu.edu/aboutus.html|title=Welcome to Aggieland Yearbook â About Us|publisher=Texas A&M University|accessdate=2009-04-05}}{{cite web|url=http://aggieland.tamu.edu/history.html|title=Welcome to Aggieland Yearbook- History|publisher=Texas A&M University|accessdate=2007-04-05}} The university houses the public broadcasting stations: ''[[KAMU-TV]]'', a [[PBS]] member station since 1970, ''[[KAMU-FM]]'' an [[National Public Radio|NPR]] affiliate since 1977,{{cite web|url=http://www.kbtx.com/home/headlines/6798412.html|title=KAMU-FM Celebrates Anniversary with HD Preview|publisher=[[KBTX]]|date=2007-03-30|accessdate=2007-04-05|last=Feltman|first=Brittney|coauthors=Murphy, Chace}} and the student-run ''[[KANM]]'', "the college station of [[College Station, Texas|College Station]]".{{cite web|url=http://kanm.tamu.edu/home.php?filetoinclude=history.php|title=About KANM|publisher=Texas A&M University|accessdate=2007-04-05}} W5AC broadcast the first live, play-by-play broadcast of a college football game, at Kyle Field, in November 1921. The game, played in Dallas between Aggies and [[Texas Longhorns|University of Texas]], ended in a scoreless tie.{{cite web|last=Schultz|first=Charles R.|title=First Play-by-Play Radio Broadcast of a College Football Game|publisher=Brazos County Historical Commission|format=PDF|year=2003|url=http://www.brazoscountyhistory.org/sites/bchc/files/EarlyFootballBroadcast.pdf|accessdate=2009-04-05}} == Traditions == {{Main|Traditions of Texas A&M University}} {{See also|List of Texas Aggie terms}} [[File:AggieRing.jpg|thumb|right|Aggie Ring for the class of 2004|alt=Close-up of gold ring. On the top, the words Texas A&M University 1876 encircle an eagle atop a shield over the numbers 0 and 4. The left side contains a large star and an oak. The right shows a cannon, saber, and rifle with the crossed flags of the United States and Texas.]] The Texas A&M culture is a product of the university's founding as a rural military and agricultural school. Although the school and surrounding community have grown, and military training is no longer required, the [[History of Texas A&M University|school's history]] has instilled in students "the idealized elements of a small-town life: community, tradition, loyalty, optimism, and unabashed sentimentality."{{Cite news|last=Burka|first=Paul|title=The Aggie Bonfire Tragedy|newspaper=[[Texas Monthly]]|date=April 2000|page=116|edition=Vol. 28, Issue 4|postscript=}} ''[[Texas Monthly]]'' posits that Texas A&M students' respect for school [[traditions]] and values is the university's greatest strength.{{Cite news|last=Burka|first=Paul|title=Agent of Change|newspaper=[[Texas Monthly]]|date=November 2006|pages=155â159, 250â264|postscript=}} Some of the school traditions date to the 1890s, while others have been introduced more recently. These traditions help current and former students to cultivate the Aggie Spirit, a sense of loyalty and respect for the school.{{Cite news|last=Tresaugue|first=Matthew|title=Gift has nice ring to it|newspaper=[[Houston Chronicle]]|page=A1, A8| date=July 7, 2007|postscript=}} They dictate many aspects of student life, including how to greet others (using the official school greeting "Howdy!"),{{Cite news | last=Hallett | first=Vicky | title=The Aggie Way of Life | newspaper=[[U.S. News & World Report]] | year=2005 | url=http://www.usnews.com/usnews/edu/college/articles/brief/05texas_brief.php| accessdate = 2007-06-25 | archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20050826033718/http://www.usnews.com/usnews/edu/college/articles/brief/05texas_brief.php | archivedate=2005-08-26 | postscript=}} how to act at an A&M sporting event, and, in many cases, what words a student may use in conversation.{{Cite news|title=Memorandum|last=Gravois|first=John|date=January 5, 2007|newspaper=[[The Chronicle of Higher Education]]|volume=53|issue=18|page=A6|edition=Short Subjects|postscript=}} The most visible tradition among seniors and former students is the wearing of the [[Aggie Ring]], whose design has been relatively unchanged since its introduction in 1894.{{Cite news|last=Kane|first=Maureen|title=Tradition sets A&M aside as the oldest institution of higher learning in Texas|newspaper=[[The Battalion]]|date=October 30, 2001|url=http://media.www.thebatt.com/media/storage/paper657/news/2001/10/03/Ams125th/Tradition.Sets.Am.Aside.As.The.Oldest.Institution.Of.Higher.Learning.In.Texas-515916.shtml|accessdate=2007-06-30|postscript=}} Students may order a ring after completing 90 [[credit hours]] of coursework, including at least 45 hours at A&M, or after graduation. Graduate students may receive a ring after 75% of their graduate coursework is completed or after the acceptance of their dissertation or thesis.{{cite web|url=http://www.aggienetwork.com/ring/csreqs.aspx|title=Aggie Ring Requirements|accessdate=2007-05-24|publisher=The Association of Former Students}} Though unsanctioned by the University, many students "dunk" their newly acquired Aggie Rings into a pitcher of beer and quickly chug the entire pitcher to "earn" the ring. Some students dunk their rings in alternative substances, including ice cream or nonalcoholic beverages.{{Cite news|last=Wirt|first=Ashley|url=http://media.www.thebatt.com/media/storage/paper657/news/2006/09/14/News/Aggies.Find.New.Ways.Of.ring.Dunking-2271747.shtml|title=Aggies find new ways of 'ring dunking'|date=2006-11-09|accessdate=2007-05-18|newspaper=The Battalion|postscript=}} [[File:AggieMuster.jpg|thumb|left|The [[Texas A&M University Corps of Cadets#Ross Volunteers|Ross Volunteers]] perform a rifleman's [[salute]] as candles are lit for the deceased at the 2007 [[Muster (Texas A&M University)|Aggie Muster]] at [[Reed Arena]].]] In keeping with the idea that all current and former students comprise a family, Aggies have created two traditions to honor members of the Aggie family who have died. [[Muster (Texas A&M University)|Aggie Muster]] is held annually on the anniversary of the [[Battle of San Jacinto]], April 21, to honor any current and former student who died during the previous year. Over 300 Musters are held around the world, with the largest taking place at [[Reed Arena]] on the [[Texas A&M University campus]].{{Cite news|last=Lozano|first=Juan A.|title=Especially solemn rite of Muster|date=April 22, 2000|url=http://www.chron.com/CDA/archives/archive.mpl?id=2000_3209862|accessdate=2007-08-16|newspaper=Houston Chronicle|postscript=}} All Muster ceremonies feature the Roll Call for the Absent. As the names of the deceased Aggies are called, a family member or friend answers "Here" and lights a candle, to symbolize that although their loved one is not present in body, his or her spirit will shine forever.{{Cite news|last=Lopez|first=John P.|title=Tragedy strikes A&M family|date=November 26, 2002|newspaper=Houston Chronicle|accessdate=2007-08-16|url=http://www.chron.com/CDA/archives/archive.mpl?id=2002_3603773|postscript=}}{{Cite document |last=Eisterhold|first=Michelle|publisher=Houston Community Newspapers|title=Klein youth killed while walking near A&M campus|date=October 18, 2006 |url=http://www.hcnonline.com/site/index.cfm?newsid=17343968|accessdate=2008-06-23 |postscript=}}{{dead link|date=September 2010}} The event received worldwide attention during [[World War II]], when 25 Aggies "mustered" during the [[Battle of Corregidor|battle]] for the island of [[Corregidor]].{{Cite news|last=Tutt|first=Bob|title=Enemy shells at Corregidor couldn't stop Aggie Muster|newspaper=Houston Chronicle|date=April 16, 1994|accessdate=2007-08-16|url=http://www.chron.com/CDA/archives/archive.mpl?id=1994_1196332|postscript=}} Students who die while enrolled at Texas A&M are also honored at Silver Taps, a ceremony held, when necessary, on the first Tuesday of the month. This tradition began as a memorial for former Texas A&M president [[Lawrence Sullivan Ross]].{{Cite news|last=Hegstrom|first=Edward|title='Silver Taps' honors Aggie Bonfire victims|date=December 8, 1999|newspaper=Houston Chronicle|url=http://www.chron.com/CDA/archives/archive.mpl?id=1999_3182335|accessdate=2007-08-16|postscript=}} On the day of the ceremony, flags fly half-staff and notices are posted throughout campus. At 10:15 p.m. the lights around campus are extinguished and hymns chime from Albritton Tower while students and faculty collect in the Academic Plaza. Following a [[21-gun salute]] by the Ross Volunteer Firing Squad, six [[Bugle (instrument)|buglers]] play an A&M version of the song ''[[Taps]]'', Silver Taps, three times from the dome of the school's Academic Building: once to the north, the south and to the west. The song is not played to the east symbolizing that the sun will never rise on that Aggie again. === Sports === [[File:2007-SBF.jpg|thumb|upright|right|The 2007 Student Bonfire|alt=Large flames engulf the top layer of a circular three-tier structure of logs; the logs are vertical to the ground.]] ==== 12th Man ==== Aggie [[college football|football]] fans are called the [[12th Man (football)|12th Man]], meaning they are there to support the 11 players on the field, willing to enter the game, if necessary. To further symbolize their "readiness, desire, and enthusiasm," the entire student body stands throughout the game.{{Cite document |url = http://aggietraditions.tamu.edu/12thman.shtml |title = Twelfth Man |accessdate = 2006-12-31 |date = |publisher = Texas A&M University |postscript = }} The tradition began on January 2, 1922, at the [[Dixie Classic (bowl game)|Dixie Classic]] where A&M played [[Centre College]]. A&M had so many injuries in the first half of the game that [[head coach|Coach]] [[Dana X. Bible]] feared he wouldnât have enough men to finish the game. He called into the stands for [[E. King Gill#History|E. King Gill]], a reserve who had left football after the regular season to play basketball. Although he did not actually play, his readiness symbolized the willingness of all Aggies to support their team to the point of actually entering the game. A&M won 22â14, but E. King Gill was the only man left standing on the sidelines for the Aggies.{{cite web|last=Cook|first=Beano|title=Ten Days That Shook the Sport|publisher=Espn.Com|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/news/story?id=2615391|date=October 8, 2006|accessdate=2007-07-26|postscript=}} In recent decades, the 12th Man is represented on the field by a [[Walk-on (sport term)|walk-on]] player who wears the No. 12 jersey and participates in kick-offs.{{cite news|last=Heater|first=Jay|title=LaMantia A&M's Main 12th Man|publisher=Oakland Tribune|date=2006-12-27|url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4176/is_20061227/ai_n17077154/|accessdate=2007-04-30}} {{dead link| date=May 2010 | bot=DASHBot}} The 12th Man uses a variety of school yells, rather than cheers, to support Aggie teams. Each year the student body elects five students to serve as the Yell Leaders.{{Cite news | last =Alvarado | first =Nicole | title = Yell Leaders represent Aggie Spirit past, present, and future | newspaper=[[The Battalion]] | date=April 20, 2007 | url =http://media.www.thebatt.com/media/storage/paper657/news/2007/04/20/News/Yell-Leaders.Represent.Aggie.Spirit.Past.Present.And.Future-2870762.shtml | accessdate=2007-05-29 | postscript =}} At [[midnight]] before each home [[American football|football]] game at Kyle Field or at a predesignated location at away games, the fans gather together to practice the yells for the next day's game. Led by the Yell Leaders, and the Fightin' Texas Aggie Band, the Twelfth Man files into the stadium to participate in [[Midnight Yell Practice]] to practice yells, sing the [[wikisource:Aggie War Hymn|War Hymn]], and joke about their opponents. At the conclusion of the yell practice, the stadium lights are extinguished and fans kiss their dates. This is also done as practice, because Aggies are expected to "mug down", or kiss their dates, every time the football team scores on the field.{{cite web|last=Drehs|first=Wayne|title=Follow the yell leaders!|date=November 26, 2003|publisher=ESPN.Com|url=http://espn.go.com/page2/s/drehs/031126texasam.html|accessdate=2007-06-30|postscript=}}{{Cite news|last=Haskins|first=Maggie|title=The Perfect Week|newspaper=[[Sports Illustrated]]|date=November 4, 2004|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2004/sioncampus/11/03/perfect1104/|accessdate=2007-08-20|postscript=}} ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'' named Midnight Yell as one of the "100 Things You Gotta Do Before You Graduate."{{cite web|last=|first=|title=The 100 Things You Gotta Do Before You Graduate (Whatever the Cost)|date=September 24, 2003|publisher=SI.Com ([[Sports Illustrated]])|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2003/sioncampus/09/24/100_things0930/|accessdate=2007-06-30|postscript=}} ==== Bonfire ==== Almost every year since 1909, A&M students have built a large bonfire to celebrate their "burning desire to beat the hell outta" the University of Texas.{{cite journal|last=Smith|first=Jonathan M.|year=2007|title=The Texas Aggie Bonfire: A Conservative Reading of Regional Narratives, Traditional Practices, and a Paradoxical Place|newspaper=Annals of the Association of American Geographers|pages=182â201|url=http://www.blackwell-synergy.com/action/showFullText?submitFullText=Full+Text+HTML&doi=10.1111%2Fj.1467-8306.2007.00530.x&cookieSet=1#Two%20Southern%20Narratives|accessdate=2007-08-15|doi=10.1111/j.1467-8306.2007.00530.x|journal=Annals of the Association of American Geographers|volume=97|postscript=}}{{dead link|date=September 2010}} [[Aggie Bonfire]] was traditionally lit around [[Thanksgiving]] in conjunction with the festivities surrounding the annual [[college football]] game between the schools. Though it began as a trash pile,{{Cite news | title = Vanities of the Bonfire | newspaper = [[American Scientist]] | date = November - December 2000 | url =http://www.americanscientist.org/template/AssetDetail/assetid/23826/page/2;jsessionid=aaa5LVFO | accessdate = 2007-02-28 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20071201065643/http://www.americanscientist.org/template/AssetDetail/assetid/23826/page/2;jsessionid=aaa5LVFO |archivedate = December 1, 2007|deadurl=yes | postscript = }} Aggie Bonfire evolved into a massive six-tiered structure, the world record being held at {{convert|109|ft|m|-1}}.{{Cite news|last = Bernstein|first = Alan| title = Aggie Bonfire holds distinction as Texas symbol|newspaper= [[The Houston Chronicle]] | date = November 18, 1999 | url =http://www.chron.com/disp/story.mpl/special/bonfire/386353.html | accessdate = 2007-02-28 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20071225220124/http://www.chron.com/disp/story.mpl/special/bonfire/386353.html |archivedate = December 25, 2007|deadurl=yes|postscript = }} {{Wayback|url=http://www.chron.com/disp/story.mpl/special/bonfire/386353.html|date =20070214235959|bot=DASHBot}} {{cite web|url=http://www.salon.com/books/it/1999/12/08/bonfire/index.html|title=Memories of an Aggie bonfire boy |publisher=[[Salon.com]]|accessdate=2007-08-14|postscript=}} After the collapse of the 1999 structure, causing the death of 11 students and one former student, the university suspended Bonfire indefinitely, but the tradition continues off-campus without direct University involvement, sanction, or participation.{{Cite news | last = Milloy | first = Ross E.| title = National Briefing | newspaper=[[The New York Times]] | url =http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9E03E5DA113DF936A35751C0A9649C8B63|date=February 5, 2002 | accessdate = 2007-03-03 | postscript = | unused_data = Southwest: Texas: Aggie President Cancels Bonfire }}{{Cite news | title = Off-campus Texas A&M bonfire brings out thousands | newspaper=[[The Badger Herald]] | url =http://badgerherald.com/news/2002/11/26/offcampus_texas_a_m_.php|date=November 26, 2002 | accessdate = 2007-03-03 | postscript = }} == Athletics == {{Main|Texas A&M Aggies}} [[File:Texas A&M University aTm logo.svg|right|thumb|TAMU logo]] A charter member of the [[Southwest Conference]] until its dissolution in 1996, A&M will compete in the [[Big 12 Conference]] until June 2012. The Aggies will compete in the [[Southeastern Conference]] in all sports starting July 2012.{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/college-football/story/_/id/7019493/texas-officially-gets-accepted-sec |title=Texas A&M Aggies officially get accepted into the SEC |publisher=Espn|date=2008-01-01 |accessdate=2011-09-26}}{{cite news|title=TEXAS HISTORY HIGHLIGHTS:A Look Back at the Southwest Conference|publisher=Dallas Morning News|year=2007|url=http://www.texasalmanac.com/history/highlights/swc/|accessdate=2007-05-07}} The school's 20 sports teams are known as the [[Texas Aggie|Aggies]], and the school's colors are [[Maroon (color)|maroon]] and [[white]].{{cite web|title=Texas A&M Aggies|publisher=[[Big 12 Conference]]|url=http://www.big12sports.com/schools/tam/big12-tam-body.html|accessdate=2007-04-30|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070416115959/http%3A//www.big12sports.com/schools/tam/big12-tam-body.html |archivedate = April 16, 2007|deadurl=yes}} As of April 2011, Aggies have earned 138 Southwest
