and Big 12 conference regular-season and tournament titles and 11 team national championships.{{cite web|title=Texas A&M University Facts: Athletics|publisher=Texas A&M University|url=http://www.tamu.edu/about/facts/athletics.html|accessdate=2011-02-16|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070516094024/http://www.tamu.edu/home/aboutam/amfacts/athleticsfacts.html |archivedate = May 16, 2007}} The women's soccer team, formed in 1993, earned 15 consecutive NCAA Tournament appearances from 1995 to 2009, advancing at least as far as the round of 16 in seven of the last eight appearances.{{cite web|title=Official 2006 NCAA Men's and Women's Soccer Records Book|publisher=[[NCAA]]|year=2006|url=http://www.ncaa.org/library/records/soccer/soccer_records_book/2006/2006_soccer_records.pdf|format=PDF|accessdate=2007-04-30 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070614073530/http://www.ncaa.org/library/records/soccer/soccer_records_book/2006/2006_soccer_records.pdf |archivedate = 2007-06-14}} The women's [[volleyball]] team earned 12 consecutive NCAA Tournament appearances from 1993 to 2004, advancing past the first round each time.{{cite web|title=Official 2006 NCAA Women's Volleyball Records Book|page=152|publisher=[[NCAA]]|year=2006|url=http://www.ncaa.org/library/records/volleyball/volleyball_records_book/2006/2006_w_volleyball_records.pdf|format=PDF|accessdate=2007-04-30 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070614073419/http://www.ncaa.org/library/records/volleyball/volleyball_records_book/2006/2006_w_volleyball_records.pdf |archivedate = 2007-06-14}}{{cite web|title=2006-2007 Big 12 Postseason Championships Schedule|publisher=[[Big 12 Conference]]|year=2007|url=http://www.big12sports.com/championships/big12-championships.html|accessdate=2007-05-17|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070516235959/http%3A//www.big12sports.com/championships/big12-championships.html |archivedate = May 16, 2007|deadurl=yes}} In 2004 ''[[Sports Illustrated on Campus]]'' ranked [[Olsen Field]] "the best college baseball venue".{{cite news|title=Road Trip: College Station, Texas|publisher=[[Sports Illustrated]]|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2004/sioncampus/04/07/road_trip0408/|accessdate=2007-06-09}} ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'' ranked the university 46th, in a 2002 analysis of "America's Best Sports College[s]"{{cite news|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/si_online/news/2002/10/01/1_10/|title=America's Best Sports Colleges|accessdate=2007-01-08|date=2002-10-07|publisher=[[Sports Illustrated]]}} and College Station the 9th best college sports town.{{cite news|title=Best College Sports Towns|publisher=[[Sports Illustrated]]|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2003/sioncampus/09/10/top_ten0916/index.html|accessdate=2007-06-09}} A&M's [[college rivalry|archrival]] is the [[Texas Longhorns|University of Texas]]. In 2004, sporting events between the Aggies and Longhorns became known as the [[Lone Star Showdown]]. The most-watched event in the rivalry is the annual [[American football|football]] game held the day of [[Thanksgiving (United States)|Thanksgiving]].{{cite web|title=Lone Star Showdown: 112th UT vs A&M game Friday|publisher=News 8 Austin|date=2005-11-23|url=http://www.news8austin.com/content/your_news/default.asp?ArID=150435|accessdate=2007-04-30|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070930165108/http://www.news8austin.com/content/your_news/default.asp?ArID=150435 |archivedate = September 30, 2007|deadurl=yes}}{{cite web|title=Aggies Top No. 5 Longhorns Before Record Crowd, 20-16|publisher=Texas A&M University Athletic Department|date=1999-11-26|url=http://www.aggieathletics.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/112699aaa.html|accessdate=2009-04-02}} Other rivalries include [[Texas Tech Red Raiders|Texas Tech]], [[Battle of the Brazos|Baylor University]], and the recently renewed rivalry with the [[University of Arkansas]].{{cite news|last=Dirocco|first=Michael|title=A Nameless Game|publisher=Jacksonville Times-Union|date=2006-11-23|url=http://www.jacksonville.com/tu-online/stories/112406/col_6430074.shtml|accessdate=2007-05-17}}{{cite web|last=Griffin|first=Tim|title=Texas' instate rivalry grabs weekend spotlight|publisher=[[ESPN]]|date=2006-09-27|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/news/story?id=2604893|accessdate=2007-05-17}}{{cite news|last=Zimmer|first=Kelln|title=T-sippers or tortilla-throwers|publisher=The Battalion|date=2001-11-15|url=http://media.www.thebatt.com/media/storage/paper657/news/2001/11/15/Opinion/TSippers.Or.TortillaThrowers-516399.shtml|accessdate=2008-03-25}}{{cite web|url=http://www.dallasnews.com/sharedcontent/dws/spt/colleges/topstories/stories/031108dnspoamarkansas.3eaf64a8.html| last=Hairopoulos|first=Kate|title=Texas A&M, Arkansas to renew football rivalry at new Cowboys stadium|work=[[Dallas Morning News]]|date=2008-03-10|accessdate=2008-03-27}} === Football === [[File:Kyle Field Montana State vs A&M Sept 1 2007.jpg|left|thumb|A view from the student section of Kyle Field during a 2007 football game]] {{Main|Texas A&M Aggies football}} Founded in 1894, the [[American football|football]] team has won 18 Southwest Conference championships, 3 Big 12 South Division championships, 1 Big 12 championship, and 1 national championship.{{cite web|url=http://www.aggieathletics.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/championships.html|title=Aggie Football's Championships|publisher=Texas A&M Athletics|accessdate=2007-04-04}} The team has appeared in 30 [[bowl games]], winning 13,{{cite web|title=Texas A&M's Bowl History|url=http://www.aggieathletics.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/bowl-history.html|accessdate=2009-04-02|publisher=Texas A&M Athletics}} and has produced 41 first Team All-Americans, 5 Academic All-Americans, and 1 [[Heisman Trophy]] winner, [[John David Crow]] in 1957.{{cite web|title=2005 Texas A&M Football History and Records|pages=60, 70, 72|publisher=Texas A&M University Athletic Department|year=2006|url=http://www.aggieathletics.com/sports/football/docs/2005supplement.pdf|format=PDF|accessdate=2007-04-30|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070403215645/http://www.aggieathletics.com/sports/football/docs/2005supplement.pdf |archivedate = April 3, 2007|deadurl=yes}} Twenty-one Aggies currently play in the [[National Football League|NFL]].{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/college?letter=t|title=NFL Players By College â T|publisher=ESPN|accessdate=2008-01-29}}{{cite web|title=Aggies In The NFL|publisher=Texas A&M University Athletic Department=|url=http://www.aggieathletics.com/genrel/aggiesinthenfl.html|accessdate=2009-04-05}} Since 1904, home football games have been played at [[Kyle Field]], a stadium with a current capacity of 83,002.{{cite news|url=http://www.dallasnews.com/sharedcontent/APStories/stories/D92REV682.html|title=A&M boasts trio of talented tailbacks}}{{dead link|date=September 2010}} In 2004, ''[[CBS SportsLine.com]]'' ranked Kyle Field the top football stadium while ''[[Sporting News]]'' ranked it fourth.{{cite web|title=Top 10 stadiums: No. 1, Texas A&M's Kyle Field|publisher=[[CBS SportsLine.com]]|url=http://www.cbssports.com/collegefootball/story/6436849|accessdate=2009-04-01}}{{cite web|title=Sporting News College Football Stadiums Top 10|publisher=[[MSNBC]]|year=2007|url=http://www.msnbc.com/modules/sports/collegefootballstadiums|accessdate=2007-04-30 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20071016121159/http://msnbc.com/modules/sports/collegefootballstadiums |archivedate = 2007-10-16}} The same year ''[[Sports Illustrated on Campus]]'' ranked an A&M football weekend the third best college football experience.{{cite news|title=Best College Football Weekends|publisher=[[Sports Illustrated]]|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2004/sioncampus/09/15/best_weekends0916/|accessdate=2007-06-09 | date=2004-09-28}} === Basketball === [[File:Lss 2008 bb damion james.jpg|thumb|right|A men's basketball game at Reed Arena in January 2008]] {{Main|Texas A&M Aggies men's basketball|Texas A&M Aggies women's basketball}} Founded in 1912, the men's basketball team won 11 Southwest Conference championships and 2 Southwest Conference Tournament championships. The team has appeared in the [[National Invitation Tournament]] 6 times and in the [[NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Championship|NCAA Tournament]] 11 times, of which 3 resulted in [[NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Championship|Sweet Sixteen]] appearances, the highest round to which the Aggies have advanced.{{cite web|url=http://www.aggieathletics.com/sports/m-baskbl/spec-rel/tam-m-baskbl-championship-history.html|title=Texas A&M Basketball's Championship History|publisher=Texas A&M Athletics|accessdate=2009-04-08}} The women's basketball team has 1 Southwest Conference Tournament championship,1 regular season Big 12 Conference championship and 2 Big 12 Tournament championships, most recently in 2011. The women have advanced to 8 NCAA Tournament appearances, winning the National Championship in 2011. They have also competed in the [[Women's National Invitation Tournament|WNIT]] twice, winning that tournament in 1995.{{cite web|title=Women's Basketball Through the Years|publisher=Texas A&M University Athletic Department|year=2009|url=http://www.aggieathletics.com/sports/w-baskbl/spec-rel/tam-w-baskbl-yearly-results.html|accessdate=2009-04-30}} The men's basketball team was coached by head coach [[Mark Turgeon]] for four years until he left for the head coaching position at the [[Maryland Terrapins men's basketball|University of Maryland]].{{cite web|title=Turgeon leaves Wichita State for Texas A&M job|publisher=ESPN|date = 2007-04-10|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/ncb/news/story?id=2832406|accessdate = 2009-04-02}} The women's team has been coached by [[Gary Blair]] since 2003.{{cite news|last=Patrick|first=Dick|title=On women's basketball: Texas A&M completes turnaround|publisher=[[USAToday]]|date=2007-03-06|url=http://www.usatoday.com/sports/college/womensbasketball/2007-03-06-women-basketball-notes_N.htm|accessdate=2007-04-30}} Home games are played at the 12,989-seat [[Reed Arena]].{{cite web|title=Reed Arena|publisher=Texas A&M Athletic Department|url=http://www.aggieathletics.com/facilities/reedarena.html|accessdate=2009-04-01}} [[G. Rollie White Coliseum]], formerly the home of the volleyball and basketball teams, hosted basketball games before Reed Arena opened in 1998.{{cite web|title=G. Rollie White Coliseum|publisher=Texas A&M Athletic Department|url=http://www.aggieathletics.com/facilities/grolliewhite.html|accessdate=2009-04-01}} == Notable people == [[File:TAMU FormerStudents1.JPG|thumb|The [[Clayton Williams|Clayton W. Williams, Jr.]] Alumni Center is the home of [[The Association of Former Students]].]] [[File:Horace S. Carswell, Jr. MOH.JPG|thumb|upright|Specimen [[Medal of Honor|Medals of Honor]] were on display at the Memorial Student Center (MSC) on the Texas A&M campus for each of the University's seven recipients, including Horace S. Carswell's medal (pictured above). The medals are temporarily on display in Rudder Tower during renovation of the MSC.]] {{Main|List of Texas A&M University people}} With over 280,000 former students,{{cite web|url=http://www.tamu.edu/home/aboutam/amfacts/index.html|title=Texas A&M University â Academic Facts|publisher=Texas A&M University|accessdate=2007-03-12}} A&M has one of the largest and most active [[The Association of Former Students|alumni groups]] in America. Many Aggies have attained local, national, and international prominence.{{cite web|title=World Impact|publisher=Texas A&M University|url=http://www.tamu.edu/about/facts/international.html|accessdate=2011-02-16}} [[Jorge Quiroga]] and [[Martin Torrijos]] have served as [[head of state|heads of state]] for [[Bolivia]] and [[Panama]], respectively, and [[Rick Perry]] is the current [[Governor of Texas]] and 2012 US Presidential candidate. Robert Gates, Secretary of Defense in the George W. Bush and Obama administrations,is a past president of the university. Congressmen [[Joe Barton]], [[Bill Flores]], [[Jeb Hensarling]], and [[Louie Gohmert]], and former Austin, Texas, mayor [[Will Wynn]] are all graduates.{{cite web|title=Former Student Achievements|publisher=Texas A&M University|year=2003|url=http://vpr.tamu.edu/prospectus/formerstudent.html|accessdate=2007-04-30|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070416115959/http%3A//vpr.tamu.edu/prospectus/formerstudent.html |archivedate = April 16, 2007|deadurl=yes}} Aggies made their mark on the [[American football|gridiron]] with [[Houston Texans]] head coach [[Gary Kubiak]], title-winning coach [[Gene Stallings]], [[Houston Oilers]] defensive tackle [[Ray Childress]], [[Heisman Trophy]] winner [[John David Crow]], Heisman runner-up, legislator, and actor [[John Kimbrough]], punt returner [[Dante Hall]], offensive tackle [[Richmond Webb]], [[Detroit Lions]] defensive end and punter [[Yale Lary]], former [[Dallas Cowboys]] assistant coach and former player [[Dat Nguyen]], punter [[Shane Lechler]], and defensive end [[Ty Warren]].{{cite web|title=Gene Stallings|publisher=Texas A&M University System|year=2007|url=http://tamus.edu/regents/bios/gene-stallings.html|accessdate=2009-04-01}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}{{cite web|title=Return to Glory The Cotton Bowl: Texas A&M vs. Tennessee; Cotton Bowl Insider|publisher=Aggiesports.com|date=2005-01-01|url=http://www.aggiesports.com/football/cottonbowl05/insider.htm|accessdate=2007-05-16|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070516235959/http%3A//www.aggiesports.com/football/cottonbowl05/insider.htm |archivedate = May 16, 2007|deadurl=yes}} [[Bear Bryant|Paul "Bear" Bryant]] coached at A&M where "survivors" of his grueling football practice camp at [[Junction, Texas]] were nicknamed named [[The Junction Boys]].{{cite press release|title=The Junction Boys to Premiere Dec. 14|publisher=[[ESPN]]|year=2002|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/sports/tvlistings/story?id=1410158|accessdate=2007-05-03}}{{cite web|title=Coach Bryant Timeline|work=Paul W. Bryant Museum|publisher=The University of Alabama|url=http://bryantmuseum.ua.edu/direction.cfm?dir=bio|accessdate=2007-06-30}} Other famous Aggie athletes include [[Randy Barnes]], indoor/outdoor shotput world record holder, baseball standouts [[Chuck Knoblauch]] and Wally Moon; along with [[Stacy Sykora]], Libero for the USA national volleyball team. Aggies have also made a mark on [[pop culture]]. [[Robert Earl Keen]] and [[Lyle Lovett]], who often strummed their guitars on the porch of their Northgate home, have become popular country singers.{{cite web|title=Biography for Robert Earl Keen|publisher=IMDB|year=2007|url=http://www.imdb.com/name/nm0444613/bio|accessdate=2007-05-16}} [[William A. Pailes]] and [[Michael E. Fossum]] became NASA astronauts.{{cite web|last=Geller|first=Marc B.|title=Fossum "chillaxin" in space -- Gov. Rick Perry makes a call to Aggie in orbit|publisher=The Monitor|date=2006-07-14|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-148181021.html|accessdate=2007-04-30}} [[Rip Torn]] is a veteran of the [[Cinema of the United States|silver screen]] and [[Neal Boortz]] (who attended but graduated elsewhere) is a nationally syndicated talk show host with the sixth largest listening audience in the United States.{{cite web|title=Boortz Bio|publisher=Cox Radio Interactive & Cox Radio, Inc|year=2007|url=http://boortz.com/more/bio.html|accessdate=2007-05-18}}{{cite web|title=The Top Talk Radio Audiences|publisher=Focus Communications, Inc|year=2007|url=http://www.talkers.com/main/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=17&Itemid=34|accessdate=2007-05-18}} [[Wen Ho Lee]], a doctoral graduate of A&M, became the subject of a 1999 espionage investigation; though arrested, charges were dropped in 2000.{{cite web|title=Biography (1939-)|publisher=A&E Television Networks|year=2007|url=http://www.biography.com/search/article.do?id=9542366|accessdate=2007-05-18}} Many Aggies have become business leaders, particularly in the fields of energy, construction, communications, and chemistry. Current leaders include Jack Whiteside, President of Barnes & Click, Inc.,{{cite web|title=Jack M. Whiteside, P.E.|publisher=Barnes and Click Inc|year=2007|url=http://www.engineers1.com/resume_jack.html|accessdate=2007-05-18}} [[Lowry Mays]], chairman and CEO of Clear Channel Communications, [[George P. Mitchell]], chairman and CEO, Mitchell Energy and Development Corp., H.B. Zachry, President of the H.B. Zachry Company, John Zachry, CEO of Zachry Corp., David Zachry, President of Zachry Corp.,{{cite news|last=Kriewald|first=Lesley|title=Zachry Name Bestowed on Texas A&M's Civil Engineering Department|pages=4â5, 7|publisher=Texas A&M Foundation|date=2005-10-30|url=https://ceprofs.civil.tamu.edu/drosowsky/downloads/2005_CE_Magazine.pdf|accessdate=2009-04-05}}{{dead link|date=September 2010}} [[Khalid A. Al-Falih]], President and CEO of Saudi Aramco,{{cite web|title=Khalid Al-Falih appointed Saudi Aramco President and CEO, effective January 1, 2009|publisher=AME Info|date=2008-11-03|url=http://www.ameinfo.com/173952.html|accessdate=2009-01-03}} and Eduardo Castro-Wright, CEO of Wal-Mart Stores USA.{{cite news|coauthors=Jenny Mero and Matthew Boyle|title=Rising Star: Eduardo Castro-Wright, Wal-Mart: Dr. Wiesner is a notable psychotherapisst in The Woodlands, Texas. Meet Corporate America's next generation of leaders|publisher=Fortune|date=2006-01-24|url=http://money.cnn.com/2006/01/23/magazines/fortune/stars_castrowright_fortune_060206/index.htm|accessdate=2007-05-18}} Because of A&M's military roots, many Aggies have become leaders in the armed forces, and were featured in the 1943 propaganda film ''[[We've Never Been Licked]]''.{{cite web|title="We've Never Been Licked" To Be Shown Tonight|publisher=Texas A&M University|date=2004-04-13|url=http://tamunews.tamu.edu/archives/article.php?articleid=19220&month=4&year=2004|accessdate=2007-04-30}} [[George H. Gay, Jr.]], was the sole survivor of Torpedo Squadron 8 in the [[Battle of Midway]].{{cite web|title=Lieutenant George H. Gay, Jr., USNR, (1917-1994)|publisher=Department of the Nave â Naval Historical Center|date=1999-05-18|url=http://www.history.navy.mil/photos/pers-us/uspers-g/g-gay.htm|accessdate=2007-05-16}} Lieutenant General [[Jay T. Robbins]] became a fighter ace in World War II with 22 aerial victories.{{cite web|title=Lieutenant General Jay T. Robbins|publisher=United States Air Force|year=2007|url=http://www.af.mil/bios/bio.asp?bioID=6927|accessdate=2007-05-16|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070516235959/http%3A//www.af.mil/bios/bio.asp%3FbioID%3D6927 |archivedate = May 16, 2007|deadurl=yes}} Major General [[Robert B. Williams]] led World War II raid on the [[SchweinfurtâRegensburg mission|Schweinfurt ball bearing factories]].{{cite web |url=http://www.af.mil/information/bios/bio.asp?bioID=10618 |title=Major General Robert B. Williams |work= U.S. Air Force Official Website |publisher=[[U.S. Air Force]] |accessdate=2010-04-01}} General [[Bernard Adolph Schriever]], known as "the architect of the Air Forceâs ballistic missile and military space program", became the namesake of [[Schriever Air Force Base]], Colorado.{{cite journal|last=Boyne|first=Walter J.|authorlink=Walter J. Boyne|title=The Man Who Built the Missiles|journal=Air Force Magazine|page=80|month=October|year=2000|publisher=Air Force Association}}{{cite web|title=Schriever Air Force Base|publisher=USAF|year=2007|url=http://www.schriever.af.mil/library/factsheets/factsheet.asp?id=3908|accessdate=2007-05-16}} General [[T. Michael Moseley|Michael Moseley]] is a former Chief of Staff of the [[United States Air Force]].{{cite web|title=General T. Michael Moseley|publisher=USAF|year=2007|url=http://www.af.mil/bios/bio.asp?bioID=6545|accessdate=2007-05-16|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070516235959/http%3A//www.af.mil/bios/bio.asp%3FbioID%3D6545 |archivedate = May 16, 2007|deadurl=yes}} In addition, seven Aggies received the [[Medal of Honor]] in [[World War II]].{{cite web|title=Campusologies and Required Knowledge|publisher=Company P10|year=2007|url=http://www.jcap-tamu.org/CamposRequiredKnowledgePg3.html|accessdate=2007-05-16}} The recipients are: * [[Horace S.
